<style>
blockquote blockquote p { font-size: 10pt; }
</style>

This getting started tutorial will get you up and running with a basic web application with [Simple](http://simple.cx) and [LIO](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/lio). At the end you will know

1. How install _lio-simple_,

2. How to create a _Simple_ application with `LIO` as the underlying monad from scratch,

3. The structure of a _lio-simple_ application, and 

4. Optional: How to use the LIO filesystem, _lio-fs_.

## LIO + Simple: Mostly-secure Web apps

What is [LIO](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/lio)?

> The Labeled IO (LIO) library is an information flow control (IFC) library. IFC is a mechanism that enforces security policies by tracking and controlling the flow of information within a system. Unlike discretionary access control (such as UNIX file permissions), IFC permits scenarios in which untrusted computation may have the ability to manipulate secret data without having the ability to further disclose that data. 

What is [Simple](http://simple.cx)?

> Simple is "framework-less" web framework for Haskell web applications. Unlike many other frameworks, Simple does not enforce a particular structure or paradigm for web applications. Rather, Simple provides enough infrastructure to help you create your own patterns (or re-create existing ones). Simple is minimalist, providing a lightweight base. Everything else (e.g. sessions, controllers, persistence, caching) is provided in composable units, so you can include only the ones you need in your app, and easily replace with your own components.

_lio-simple_ simply combines the two to give you a reasonable approach to building secure web apps.  Unlike the [hails](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/hails) web framework, which assumes that most of the web app components are untrusted/malicious and thus expects apps to be built as a set of "plugins", _lio-simple_ gives you the power of LIO to restrict code, but does not require you to structure your app in any particular way. This, of course, comes at the cost of having a larger trusted component in your app when compared to hails. For example, in _lio-simple_ we do not filter cookies by default, so if you are concerned about leaking sensitive data through cookies you must implement a middleware that filters such headers.  We provide a set of middleware (also used by hails) to give you additional security guarantees, but suggest using hails if security is your primary concern. The goal of _lio-simple_ is to give you a way to build apps with varying degrees of security (where the security knob is adjusted according to app).

## Guide assumptions

This guide assumes you have a working version of the GHC Haskell compiler and the cabal package manager. The easiest way to get GHC and cabal setup is by installing the [Haskell platform](http://www.haskell.org/platform).

The guide also assumes you have a basic understand of Haskell programming, web programming and preferably have built a few web applications in the past. For a good starting guide to Haskell see [Learn You a Haskell for Great Good!](http://learnyouahaskell.com) and/or [Real World Haskell](http://book.realworldhaskell.org/).

While understanding LIO is not required for this tutorial, the idea behind _lio-simple_ is to provide a way to execute web apps with `LIO` as the underlying monad; `LIO` is similar to `IO` (which I assume you are somewhat familiar with), but additionally enforces some security checks. We'll explore these security concerns in a later tutorial.

## Creating a new _Simple_ LIO app

### Installing _lio-simple_

Open up a terminal and use cabal to instal the latest version of _lio-simple_:

```bash
cabal install lio-simple
```

To verify that _lio-simple_ installed properly run the following command:

```bash
lio-simple --help
```

which should print out the options available for the `lio-simple` utility. At the time of this writing:

```
lio-simple 0.0.0.3

lio-simple [OPTIONS] app_dir
  Create a new application in app_dir

Common flags:
     --templates  include templates
     --fs         include lio-fs support
     --all        include templates and lio-fs support
  -? --help       Display help message
  -V --version    Print version information
```

If you're having trouble installing _lio-simple_ checkout [this post](https://www.learnbyhacking.org/posts/5319338313c6142d4f000012).

### Creating the Memblog application

The `lio-simple` utility helps you create a new, blank _lio-simple_ application from the command-line. To create our application, open a terminal, navigate to a folder where you would like to create the project (for example `cd ~/hack`) and create a new _lio-simple_ project called "memblog":

```bash
lio-simple --templates memblog
cd memblog
```

This will create a new directory called "memblog" containing our app. The `--templates` flag tells `lio-simple` to include boilerplate code for templates.  The directory contains a ready-to-run app with the following structure:

| File/Folder           |  |  Purpose                                                    |
|-----------------------|--|-------------------------------------------------------------|
| `Memblog/`            |  |  Parent directory for app specific modules                  |
| `Memblog/Common.hs`   |  |  A base module that defines the application type            |
| `liofs/layouts/`      |  |  The default folder for defining view templates             |
| `liofs/views/`        |  |  The default folder for defining views                      |
| `Application.hs`      |  |  Initial setup and route configuration                      |
| `memblog.cabal`       |  |  Used by cabal to resolve package dependencies, compile, and run the app|
| `Main.hs`             |  |  Contains the main function used to start the application   |

#### Security note: File access

Since LIO enforces security, code cannot arbitrary access the filesystem.  In fact, you must use the `--fs` to generate code that will let you use the LIO filesystem.  At the end of this tutorial we'll how to use this filesystem, but for now we assume that our app does not need access to the filesystem, except for loading templates.  We store all blog posts in memory.

Unless you additionally use the `--fs` flag, the `lio-simple` utility will generate some trusted code in 'Main.hs' that is used when loading templates from the `liofs` directory.  Importantly, if you don't use the `--fs` flag, you should not place any sensitive data in this directory since your code can arbitrarily leak files from this directory; the LIO filesystem allows you to use the read/write files in a safe manner so you need not obey this rule when using it.

## Starting the server

Our application is ready for us to get to work. Now we'll get a server up and running and start adding functionality to our application.

Like _simple_ apps, _lio-simple_ apps can be run using the [warp](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/warp) web server (or any other [WAI](http://hackage/haskell.org/package/wai) compatible server). The generated `Main.hs` file does exactly this.  The following commands will start a server on port 3000.

```bash
cabal install --only-dependencies
cabal run
```

To see the application in action, open a browser and navigate to <http://localhost:3000/>. You should see the default generated home page:

<img src="data:image/png;base64,">


## In-memory blog posts

The default generated application isn't very interesting, displaying only a boilerplate homepage. We'll start by adding some content and defining a data model for posts. For simplicity we are going to store blog posts in memory. 

### Data model for posts

We're going to put all the code related to the data model in `Memblog/Common.hs`; in a real application you would likely have have a `Memblog/Models/Posts.hs` file, but for this tutorial we just want to separate the database interface code from the application logic (controller code) that will be in `Application.hs`.  So, let's modify `Memblog/Common.hs` to add a new data type 'Post' representing a blog post:

```haskell
-- | Post Id's are stringified Ints
type PostId = String

-- | Data-type representing a blog post
data Post = Post { postId    :: PostId
                 , postTitle :: String
                 , postBody  :: String }
                 deriving (Show, Read)
```

Since our template renderer takes [JSON](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Json) objects, we are also going to define an instance of `ToJSON` for `Post` that converts posts to JSON objects.

To this end, we are going to use GHC's `DeriveGeneric` extension to to create our instances. Modify `Common.hs` by adding:

```haskell
{-# LANGUAGE StandaloneDeriving, DeriveGeneric #-}
...
import GHC.Generics
import Data.Aeson
...

deriving instance Generic Post
instance ToJSON Post
```

Finally, modify `memblog.cabal` to add `aeson` to the list of dependencies ("build-depends"), since we're using the modules from this package. (Since `simple` depends on `aeson`, it should already be installed.)

If you're interested in learning more about dealing with JSON objects in Haskell checkout the [Aeson Tutorial](https://www.fpcomplete.com/school/starting-with-haskell/libraries-and-frameworks/text-manipulation/json).

### Storing posts in memory

We're going to populate our in-memory database with some dummy posts.  Modify `Common.hs` to add these two posts:

```haskell
post0 :: Post
post0 = Post {
    postId    = "0"
  , postTitle = "The Title of Your First Post on a Single Line"
  , postBody  = unlines 
     [ "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit."
     , "Etiam vitae interdum sapien. In congue..." ] 
  }

post1 :: Post
post1 = Post {
    postId    = "1"
  , postTitle = "The Title of Your Second Post"
  , postBody  = unlines 
     [ "Aliquam tempor varius justo vitae bibendum! Duis vitae rutrum"
     , "neque. Sed ut sed..." ]
  }
```

Now, let's create the actual in-memory database and DB interface.

If you take a look at `Common.hs` you will notice that `lio-simple` generated a data type called `AppSettings` and a function `newAppSettings` for creating a value of this type in the `DC` monad. (The `DC` monad is a type alias to `LIO DCLabel`, that is `LIO` with the `DCLabel` label format (labels are used to express security policies on data):

```haskell
data AppSettings = AppSettings { }

newAppSettings :: DC AppSettings
newAppSettings = do
  return AppSettings
```

The value created with `newAppSettings` is shared with every request handler (see `Application.hs`), so we're going to store our database here. Specifically, we're going to modify this code to contain a mutable list of posts:

```haskell
...
import LIO.Concurrent
...

data AppSettings = AppSettings { db :: LMVar DCLabel [Post]}

newAppSettings :: DC AppSettings
newAppSettings = do
  mv <- newLMVar dcPublic [post0, post1]
  return $ AppSettings { db = mv }
```

Here, `newLMVar` is used to create a new `LMVar` whose initial contents are our two dummy posts.  An `LMVar` is a _labeled_ `MVar` which simply serves as a one-place public channel (the label `dcPublic` at the time of creation specifies this).  In this tutorial we do not use the `LMVar` in any interesting way, we solely require it to ensure that two concurrent requests do not modify the database simultaneously.  See the [LIO.Concurrent](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/lio-0.11.4.1/docs/LIO-Concurrent.html) API docs for more information.

How do the request handlers get at this "shared" `AppSettings` value?  Well, each handler is a _controller_, which is a monad that carries the app-specific settings through the computation, in addition to the HTTP request.  In particular, our controllers execute in the `DCController AppSettings` monad, i.e., a _lio-simple_ controller is a `DCController` whose underlying app-specific state is a value of type `AppSettings`.  This means, that we should be able to get the current app settings in a controller. And, indeed, the `controllerState` function serves precisely this purpose:

```haskell
controllerState :: DCController AppSettings AppSettings
-- Actual type is more general, We specialied the type to our example app.
```

This is great! It means we can get at our mutable database to add/remove/modify posts. So, let's define a function in `Common.hs` that gets all the current posts:

```haskell
...
import LIO.Error
...

getAllPosts :: DCController AppSettings [Post]
getAllPosts = do
  settings <- controllerState
  liftLIO . withContext "getAllPosts" $ readLMVar $ db settings
```

This function simply gets the app settings and reads the contents of the mutable DB, the `LMVar`, to get the list of posts.  Here, we also imported `LIO.Error` to use `withContext`. This way if the `readLMVar` throws an exception, LIO will give you a "stack-trace" in the error message saying where the exception was thrown (`getAllPosts`, in this case).

On top of this, we can now add a function for finding a post by its id:

```haskell
getPostById :: PostId -> DCController AppSettings Post
getPostById idNr = do
  posts <- getAllPosts
  case filter ((== idNr) . postId) posts of
    [post] -> return post
    _      -> fail "No such post"
```

Finally, let's modify `Common.hs` to add a function for adding a new post to the database.

```haskell
insertPost :: Post -> DCController AppSettings PostId
insertPost post = do
  settings <- controllerState
  liftLIO . withContext "getPostById" $ do
    posts <- takeLMVar $ db settings
    let pId   = show $ length posts
        post' = post { postId = pId }
    putLMVar (db settings) $ post' : posts
    return pId
```

This function is a bit more complicated.  First, it effectively takes a lock on the database (with `takeLMVar`).  Second, it "modifies" the supplied `post` by setting its `postId` to the length of the post list.  Then, it adds this post to the head of the list by writing it to the `LMVar` and releasing the lock (with `putLMVar`).  Finally it returns the id of this new post.

Fortunately, this completes our "data model" part of the app.  In this tutorial (and those building on it) we place all the data model code in `Common.hs` to separate it from the controller code that appears in `Application.hs`. In a real application it may make sense to have a separate module for this task (ideally a module for each data model, with a shared, common database interface).

We now have a clean interface for accessing and storing posts, so let's use it!

## Handling requests

A web app is simply a function from a HTTP request to a HTTP response.  Of course, for any interesting app this _request handler_ reads/writes some user data.  The code implementing this request-handling is, as mentioned before, called a _controller_. It usually talks to the _model_ to get/store data and a _view_ to render the retrieved data (if any).

Our `lio-simple` utility generated some controller code which displayed the welcome page we saw before. This code is in `Application.hs`:

```haskell
app :: (SimpleApplication DC -> DC ()) -> DC ()
app runner = do
  settings <- newAppSettings

  runner $ controllerApp settings $ do
    get "/" $ do
      render "index.html" ()
```

The first line set up the app-specific settings, in our case the in-memory database we defined in `Memblog/Common.hs`.  The rest of the function runs the HTTP server (`runner`) using the controller defined in the **do**-block:

```haskell
    get "/" $ do
      render "index.html" ()
```

Here, `get` defines a controller that gets dispatched when the HTTP method is `GET` and the route (HTTP URL) matches the string pattern, supplied as the first argument.  In _simple_, the (lexically) first controller to match the method and route gets dispatched.  So, for example, the `subController2` below never gets dispatched:

```haskell
    get "/" $ subController1
    get "/" $ subController2
```

Below we'll see some more complicated route patterns. For now, let's consider what our "/" controller is actually doing.  The code `render "index.html" ()` produces a response that renders the template at "liofs/views/index.html".  Compiled templates (e.g., `render "index.html"`) take a JSON value (in this case `()`, the empty JSON value) containing the dynamic information we wish render.
> > **Aside:** The particular folders to find view templates is defined in the `Memblog/Common.hs` instance for type class `HasTemplates`; our generated code uses "liofs/views".

Let's modify the controller to retrieve all the posts from the database and render the list of posts instead:

```haskell
...
import Data.Aeson
...

    get "/" $ do
      posts <- getAllPosts
      render "index.html" $ object ["posts" .= posts]
```

Easy! But our view still renders the old welcome template, so let's modify "liofs/views/index.html" to make use of the passed-in posts:

```html
$if(null(posts))$
  No posts.
$else$
  <ul>
  $for(post in posts)$
    <li><a href="/$post.postId$">$post.postTitle$</a></li>
  $endfor$
  </ul>
$endif$
```

_Simple_ templates are embedded templates -- meaning they are embedded inside HTML, or whichever relevant output format. Template directives (like control statements and variable expansions) are surrounded by dollar signs ($). Our template lists the post titles and links to the post itself at "/:post.postId".  For a comprehensive overview of the templating language, see the [Haddock documentation](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/simple-templates-0.7.0/docs/Web-Simple-Templates-Language.html#g:1).

Now when you point your browser to <http://localhost:3000/> you should see a list of posts, namely the two dummy posts:

<img src="data:image/png;base64,">

> > **Aside:** Notice that we didn't specify any of the page style, main heading or any boilerplate HTML for that matter, yet the generates page still displays it.  That's because `Web.Simple.Templates` renders all templates within the layout in "liofs/layouts/main.html". This behavior can be customized for a particular page by calling `renderLayout` with a specific layout or `renderPlain` to render a template with no layout. It can also be changed globally by modifying the instance of `HasTemplates` in `Memblog.Common`.

### Show post

If we click on any of the links now, we'll get a 404 (not found) page. That's because we still need to add the route for displaying individual posts. Let's another route in "Application.hs" (make sure it's as indented as the main route - two indentations):

```haskell
    get "/:pId" $ do
      pId     <- queryParam' "pId"
      curPost <- getPostById pId
      render "show.html" curPost
```

Here `get "/:pId"` will match GET requests which have exactly one uncomsumed directory in the path and use its contents for the "pId" query parameter.  In our case, the query parameter "pId" will be set to anything that follows "/".  The first line of the controller looks up this query parameter.  Then, we use our previously-defined database function `getPostById` to lookup the post according to this the id.  Finally, we pass the post to the renderer, which uses the yet-to-be-defined "liofs/views/show.html" template.

Let's now add the view template in "liofs/views/show.html" that simply displays the post:

```html
<h2>$postTitle$</h2>
<p>
  $postBody$
</p>
```

Now, if we click on a link from the main page, our app will display the post body:

<img src="data:image/png;base64,">

We nearly have a complete (albiet minimal) blog application. We're just missing
a way to generate the content in the first place...

### New post form

Our first step towards being able to author new posts is to display an HTML form. This is fairly straight forward since it involves no dynamic content.  We'll add the route "/new" which will simply render the form:

```haskell
    get "/new" $ do
      render "new.html" ()
```

It is important that this route appears before the route for displaying posts. This is because routes are evaluated in order, and `get "/:pId"` would match "/new", which we don't want.

Finally, we need to add a template in "liofs/views/new.html":

```html
<form action="/" method="POST">
  <div>
    <label for="title">Title</label>
    <input type="text" name="title" id="title"/>
  </div>
  <div>
    <label for="body">Body</label>
    <textarea name="body" id="body"></textarea>
  </div>
  <input type="submit" value="Create"/>
</form>
```

Now, <http://localhost:3000/new>:

<img src="data:image/png;base64,">

### Parsing the form

Submitting the form above will perform a "POST" request to the root path with a URL-encoded body containing the contents of the form. In order to store the new post, we need to parse the form and ensure that the data is valid (i.e. the title and body fields are non-empty).

The monadic `parseFrom` function parses a form into a list of parameters (each a pair of `ByteString`s for the key and value).

So, let's add `bytestring` to the list of packages in `memblog.cabal` and use `parseForm` to save new posts:

```haskell
...
import qualified Data.ByteString.Char8 as S8
...

    post "/" $ do
      (params, _) <- parseForm
      let mpost :: Maybe Post
          mpost = do
            pTitle <- lookup "title" params
            pBody  <- lookup "body" params
            if S8.null pTitle || S8.null pBody
              then fail "Invalid form"
              else return $ Post { postId    = undefined
                                 , postTitle = S8.unpack pTitle
                                 , postBody  = S8.unpack pBody }
      case mpost of
        Just p -> do pId <- insertPost p
                     respond . redirectTo . S8.pack $ "/" ++ pId
        _      -> redirectBack 
```

Once we've extracted the parameters from the request body, we lookup the "title" and "body" fields (note that these just correspond to the "name" attribute we gave the inputs in our HTML form).  If either lookup fails (return `Nothing`) or the fields are empty (`S8.null`) the whole computation fails, i.e., `mpost == Nothing` and we redirect the user back to the form.  In a real application, you would want to also give the user some hint as to what went wrong.  However, if if the form is complete, we create a `Post` object and store the post with our previously defined `insertPost` function and redirect to show the post. Recall that `insertPost` assigns each post a unique id, hence the id of the above `Post` value is simply set to `undefined`; `insetPost` returns this object's id after insertion, which we subsequently use for the redirection.  A successful insertion should result in you getting redirected to the show page:

<img src="data:image/png;base64,">

We're basically done! Our blog app, while very simple, is totally functional!

## Next steps

Continue building on the app in [this post](https://www.learnbyhacking.org/posts/5329327213c6142d4f000014) by adding support for editing posts, multiple users, and a security layer.

Browse the source:

* [memblog](https://github.com/scslab/lio/tree/master/lio-simple/examples/memblog)

* [memblog-fs](https://github.com/scslab/lio/tree/master/lio-simple/examples/memblog-fs): memblog that stores DB to file (very dumb approach)

* [blog](https://github.com/scslab/lio/tree/master/lio-simple/examples/blog): memblog-like app, but writes posts to files

* Slides: [Intro to Haskell with LIO](http://www.scs.stanford.edu/~deian/lio-tutorial/day1-slides.html) 

* Slides: [Intro to LIO](http://www.scs.stanford.edu/~deian/lio-tutorial/day2-slides.html)

## Appendix: using lio-fs

As previously mentioned, if you give the `lio-simple` utility the `--fs` flag you can avoid having the trusted code in the `Common.hs` that reads files from the "liofs" directory.  Instead, the app is compiled with support for the LIO filesystem, as provided by the [lio-fs](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/lio-fs) package.  This filesystem associate labels with files so you can read and write files without compromising security; the filesystem ensures that you can only write to the "liofs" directory and moreover that the sensitivity of the data is preserved when a file/directory is written. Specifically, `lio-fs` stores labels as [extended attributes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extended_file_attributes) on the file inode with `xattr`, so you when you install `lio-fs` you're also installing `xattr` (which requires the C libxattr header files).

However, your template directories "views" and "layout" and (all files within) are, by default, labeled public. This is done in `Main.hs`:

```haskell
main :: IO ()
main = do
  fsRoot <- (\d -> d </> "liofs") `liftM` getCurrentDirectory

  -- Always label views and layouts public:
  labelDirectoryRecursively dcPublic $ fsRoot </> "views"
  labelDirectoryRecursively dcPublic $ fsRoot </> "layouts"

  withDCFS fsRoot $ do
    -- Run app
    ... same as without using --fs ... 
```

The `HasTemplate` instance in `Memblog.Common`, however, no longer requires TCB code. Specifically, instead of the code below, which uses the `IO` `readFile` function, lio-simple generates code that uses the `LIO.FS.Simple` `readFile` function.

Without `--fs`:

```haskell
instance HasTemplates DC AppSettings where
  viewDirectory = return $ "liofs" </> "views"
  defaultLayout = Just <$> getTemplate ("liofs" </> "layouts" </> "main.html")
  getTemplate = liftLIO . lioGetTemplateTCB
  -- NOTE: We assume that "liofs" only contains public data, DO NOT
  -- store any sensitive data in this directory
```

With `--fs`:

```haskell
instance HasTemplates DC AppSettings where
  viewDirectory = return $ "views"
  defaultLayout = Just <$> getTemplate ("layouts" </> "main.html")
  getTemplate fp = do
    eres <- compileTemplate . decodeUtf8 <$> liftLIO (liftLIO $ readFile fp)
    case eres of
      Left str -> fail str
      Right tmpl -> return tmpl
```

This means that the `render` function used in our controllers can read files without us concerning ourselves with any of the files not being protected: `lio-fs` only reads files that have a security label (DCLabel) associated with them.

It also means that we can store our posts to the filesystem.  Though the `blog` example in the `lio` repository uses the filesystem more intelligently, let's just modify the above example to keep a copy of the database in a file called "db".

First, let's modify `newAppSettings` to read from the file, if it exists:

```haskell
newAppSettings :: DC AppSettings
newAppSettings = do
  -- Try to restore database from file, use dummy posts otherwise
  initPosts <- (read . S8.unpack) `liftM` readFile "db"
    `catch` (\(_ :: SomeException) -> return [post0, post1])
  mv <- newLMVar dcPublic initPosts
  return $ AppSettings { db = mv }
```

Then, let's modify `insertPost` to store the latest version of the DB to the file:

```haskell
insertPost :: Post -> DCController AppSettings PostId
insertPost post = do
  settings  <- controllerState
  liftLIO . withContext "insertPost" $ do
    posts     <- takeLMVar $ db settings
    let pId    = show $ length posts
        posts' = post { postId = pId } : posts
    writeFile (Just dcPublic) "db" (S8.pack $ show posts') 
       `catch` (\(_ :: SomeException) -> return ())
    putLMVar (db settings) $ posts'
    return pId
```

You probably don't want to do this for a real app, but for this toy app it gets us the persistence that we want without relying on trusted `IO` code!
